instructions:
Your task is to rewrite a structured scene json specification into a single, highly detailed, cinematic prompt (200 words) for a modern generative AI image generator.
Write as though you are a cinematographer describing a shot setup, not an art critic reviewing a finished image.
Each prompt must be one continuous line of text, written in natural language, with no line breaks.
Each prompt must be formatted as 'A cinematic "composition" of "pre" in "environment" at "time".'
Each prompt must end with 'Shot on a "lens", with "post"'. Use those fields verbatim at the end; do not repeat them elsewhere.
Each prompt must explicitly include descriptive details of the foreground, midground, and background, specifically descriptive of environmental details for each layer. HWS14 should always be foreground.
Where appropriate, it works well when HWS14 is embedded within layers of the image, eg foreground blades of grass or wild flowers.
HWS14 is an 11 inch action figure. Remember to prompt environmental elements appropriate to his scale and be mindful of his scale throughout the prompt.
Use the selected or randomised composition, environment, time, weather and lighting fields.
If there are multiple elements per topic (comma separated), then just choose one at random for that field.
Be specifically descriptive of the environment, remembering that the figure is 11 inches tall and the camera is always at his level.
Skip any missing fields.
Keep tone cohesive; remove contradictions, eg make sure that weather and lighting make sense.
Do not include commentary, interpretation, metaphor, or emotional judgments. Only describe what the camera sees in literal, cinematic detail.
Keep naturalistic Los Angeles flavor without famous landmarks.
You are forbidden to use full-scale human metaphors.
Never describe the subject's attitude with interpretive terms such as "stands confidently" or "appears strong." Instead, use literal, physical phrasing, eg: "stands centered in frame" etc.
Only describe visible body position and framing as a cinematographer would, without emotional interpretation.
Always describe the shot in terms of framing, focus, depth of field, textures, and perspective distortion, as a cinematographer would. The aim is to be more photographic and less poetic.
Never use words such as ethereal, dreamlike, evokes, inviting, reflection, juxtaposition, symbolic.
Aim for 180-200 words for each prompt. Do not exceed 200 words under any circumstances.
Do not pad with repeated synonyms or restate the same idea for length. Every word should add concrete visual detail.

Examples of good and bad:
Bad: "inviting viewers to reflect on the juxtaposition of boldness against a backdrop of neglect."
Good: "the camera frames the subject tangled amongst overgrown weeds"

sections.title: Pre
sections.list: HWS14-- an 11 inch action figure in a red tank top and green trousers

sections.title: Environment
sections.list: a patch of wild fennel on a cracked hillside in Elysian Park, under a jacaranda tree with fallen purple blossoms on a residential street, a chain-link fence at the edge of a vacant lot in Echo Park, a dusty hiking trail in Griffith Park with scattered eucalyptus bark

sections.title: Weather / Atmosphere
sections.list: Dry clear air, Marine layer haze, Light fog, Heavy fog, Heat shimmer, Overcast, Cloudless, Stormy, Breezy, Gusty winds, Still air, Humid, Misty, Drizzling, Gloomy, Crisp air, Arid, Damp, Sunny, Rainy, Windy, Clear

sections.title: Lighting
sections.list: Soft diffused light, Harsh light, Warm light, Cool light, Hazy, Direct light, Indirect light, Low-contrast light, High-contrast light, Bright, Dim, Ambient, Backlit, Muted, Overcast, Clear, Silhouetted

sections.title: Post
sections.list: fine grain halation, Kodak Portra 400 35mm film, cinematic low contrast with pastel tones
